thread.title: Avoid food ‘poisoning’

author: washingtonpost.com
title: Avoid food ‘poisoning’
text:
October 9 at 7:44 PM The Sept. 29 Health & Science article “ Food poisoning: How three experts avoid getting sick ” used the term “food poisoning” in three places: twice in headlines and once in the article.
The food-safety industry has been trying to purge this term from the public arena for more than 20 years because it is misleading and inaccurate.
Getting sick from eating food is the result of bacteria, for the most part, that occur naturally and have to be managed and avoided in the same way we avoid getting sick in other situations.
Bacteria’s presence in food, however, is particularly dangerous because food is an excellent host and because we introduce it directly into our bodies by eating it.
Two experts Quote: d in the article used the term “food-borne illness” to describe the host of maladies that can arise from eating food that is contaminated, whether by bacteria, viruses or physical contamination. That is the correct term.
Steve Ricks ,
Arlington
